Village Square.Time: A clear and sunny morning of June 27th
Village Square.Weather: Fresh warmth of a full-summer day
Village Square.Environment: Flowers blossoming profusely and richly green grass
Village Square.Location: Situated between the post office and the bank
Village Square.Purpose: Central location for gatherings like the lottery

Children’s Play Area.Location: In a corner of the square
Children’s Play Area.Feature: Pile of stones guarded by boys
Children’s Play Area.Ground: Dusty ground where small children play or roll

Homes and Streets of the Village.Activity: Women emerge from their homes wearing house dresses and sweaters
Homes and Streets of the Village.Sounds: Sounds of children and household activities can be heard
Homes and Streets of the Village.Interaction: Village streets where family and communal interactions occur

Mr. Summers’ Coal Company.Use: A place where the lottery box is stored safely
Mr. Summers’ Coal Company.Symbolism: Symbolizes Mr. Summers’ social responsibility and civic duties

Black Box and Stool.Symbolism: Represents tradition and history of the village’s lottery rituals

Mr. Graves' Barn and Village Grocery.Use: Occasionally used to store the lottery box
Mr. Graves' Barn and Village Grocery.Symbolism: Represents locations interwoven with village traditions

Woodbridge Church Area.Symbolism: Seen as a place of solace and contemplation for Delia

Delia Jones' House.Situation: The site of domestic strife, toil, and endurance
Delia Jones' House.Description: Crammed with clothes and tools of her washing trade
Delia Jones' House.Symbolism: Represents steadfastness and determination for a life built through labor

Sykes' Encounter Points.Activity: Places where Sykes reveals his disdain and antagonizes Delia
Sykes' Encounter Points.Symbolism: Highlight societal attitudes and Sykes’ manipulative nature

Barn and Snake's Habitat.Role: Scene of ultimate confrontation and climax
Barn and Snake's Habitat.Symbolism: Represents betrayal and fear embedded in domestic spaces
